elements.text: [Part One]
Almost time.
Clock chimes two, knock on a door.
Why do you bother to knock?
Door opens and closes.
Hello, Sara. I hope the day finds you well.
When are you going to release me?
I've been told that you're eating very little. Are you unwell?
There are guards outside?
Regrettably, yes. I wish it were not necessary.
At last we agree on something.

That is progress, then, of a sort. Will you share a cup of tea with me? No? No. This is one of the planet's finest blends. Tasak has so much to offer if only you would open yourself to it. As a guest of the Argentia...
A guest? What's wrong, Magus Riga? Does the word prisoner stick in your throat?
You are not a captive, my dear.
You hold me here in this gilded cage, I'm not allowed to leave...
These apartments are among the most lavish in Argent City. Your every need is provided for. We have been excellent hosts.
I didn't ask for your... hospitality.

You are being protected, Sara. As an off-worlder you are... valuable. Your knowledge is a potential wellspring of power. Can you not understand that? Will you join us? If I must beg you, I will. Please, Sara, join our cadre, help us guide our planet towards a new shining future. Look. (opens window) Down there. Our city swells with new arrivals every day, refugees displaced by the conflicts, the desperate and the hopeful, drawn here from all across Tasak. They look to the House of Argentia, to my cadre, for stewardship. We ended the war, Sara. Now it is our burden is to begin the peace. Help me to do that.
I will never help you with the Heart.
It is our way forward.
You're tampering with something beyond your comprehension. It will destroy you. Don't you understand, Riga? You're threatening the lives of every living being on this planet.
That is not true. I would never place my people in harm's way.
Listen to me! I'm trying to warn you.
You're becoming agitated. I apologise. I did not mean to provoke you. (closes window) Perhaps it would be best if I left.
Riga, I can't help you.
Then I will make the offer again next week, and if need be the week after, and the week after that, as I have for these three months past, until you see we have only good intentions.
Door opens.
Until you say yes.
Door closes.
Guard, send for a kitchen servitor. Perhaps the food is not to her liking. It will not do for her to starve herself.
As you order, Magus.
And what if she doesn't eat? What then? Forgive me, Magus, but we indulge the off-worlder too much.
And what would you have me do, Merel? What would you do if you were Magus?
Respecttully, I believe a more aggressive approach would be expedient.
We will not compel her by force.
I only draw your attention toward an alternative.

Sara must join the House of Argentia of her own free will, or else our values mean nothing. Freedom of choice is the cornerstone of our cadre's principles. I will never allow that to be subverted. Is that clear?
Of course, sir. I did not mean to imply otherwise.
How are preparations for the Great Conclave progressing?
As planned. The delegates from the other Houses have been arriving all through the morning.
Gathering the greatest minds of every noble cadre. And the future, there ahead of us, close enough to touch.
The last ship will land just after second sunset.
The deputation from the House of Sarkota?
Of course.
Of course. They would never allow themselves to be the first to arrive, would they? That might smack of capitulation, weakness. How unhappy they must be without war.
I suppose so.

If we do this right, Merel, there will never need to be a war again. We will banish famine and disease, wipe out poverty. All our tomorrows, not just those of the Argentia or the Sarkota, they turn upon this moment. When we reveal the secrets of the Heart, we will take charge of the destiny of our world. Tasak will be forever changed.
Yes. Yes. I believe it will.

Recording. Mission file, day 20. I've tracked the energy trace to Argent City, a conurbation on the northern coast of the central continent. The trace is intermittent. I can't triangulate it yet, but I'm sure the target's here. She must have found it. (beeps) How? How could...? Mission File, additional. I have an anomaly There's a second trace here. It doesn't match any known aggressor profiles or the primary target. Far too advanced for the local tech, maybe even more advanced than ours. It's close. I'm going to investigate.
Careful not to sear the leaves. It’s quite a delicate plant. Ah. Just in time for a visitor.
[OC]: Recording. The source of the new trace appears to be some sort of blue shed.
Huh. Charming.
Tardis door opens.
[OC]: The door, it's opening. I'm proceeding inside the construction.
It's ... that's...
Rude of you. To come in without knocking, I mean.
Who are you? What is this place?
I'm the Doctor, this is the Tardis. Your turn.
Tardis door closes.
Oh no, I'm not answering any questions from a man holding a weapon on me.

This? Oh, I suppose it does appear rather dangerous from a certain point of view, doesn't it? Hmm. And I can see from your expression that you've had guns pointed at you before. You're not afraid. Careful but wary. A career soldier, perhaps? I know your kind quite well.
What is that thing, a thermal blaster? Do your worst, you'll get nothing from me.

Oh, I beg to differ. Let's have a look at you. Hmm. At first glance you seem like a, a local, but your clothes are cut too well and your teeth? Huh, they're a dead giveaway. Far too clean for someone from a pre-atomic industrial revolution era society.
You're an outsider yourself.

Everywhere I go. And then, there's that scanner you're trying to conceal in your pocket. I don't imagine Tasak science will be able to come up with something like that for a few centuries. Hand it over.
You're a human. From Earth?
I can see you might think that. (beep) Interesting. Military issue. This sort of hardware was quite common during the Orion War period.
Was?
Oh yes, well, pardon my tenses. Is. You're a covert agent, yes? Both sides deployed thousands of operatives like you during the war.
And whose side are you on, Doctor?

But that doesn't explain why you're on Tasak, does it? We're light years away from the battle lines of the Orion War. What are you doing on a backwater steam-age planet far away from your nasty little war?
Why are you here?
Me? Oh. For the tea. Care for a cup? It's really very good. Best in the quadrant.
That's... not a weapon.
I never said it was. It's a self-heating fusion teapot. Easy mistake to make, though. Biscuit, Mister, er...?
Temeter. My name is Temeter, and, er - no. No thank you.
There. Now we're being much more civilised. I should apologise, actually.
For what?

This reading. (beeping) The one that drew you here. A deliberate fiction on my part. The Tardis picked up the output from your scans of the city. I wanted to learn who was behind them. I left some cheese in the mousetrap, as it were.
You generated the second energy trace?
Yes. The second. But not the first. That one is quite a puzzle.
Do you know what it is?
Not yet. There's too much phase-wave interference. That's very unusual for such a low-tech civilisation.
I agree. But for a moment I thought it was...
Thought it was what? I'm sorry to disappoint you.
Disappoint me?
This energy trace isn't all you're looking for, is it?
I'm searching for... someone. I find the energy trace, I find her.
Perhaps we ought to pool our resources. Two heads, and so on.
Or not. No offence, Doctor, but it'll take more than tea and a biscuit to win me over.
You'll find me quite agreeable once you get to know me.
Tardis door opens.
Hmm. Maybe I should let you stick close. Just to keep an eye on you.
Funny. I was just thinking the same thing about you.
1: Lord Merel, I have the communiqué from the House of...
Well, don't announce it to everyone in the citadel. Speak.
1: I have the communiqué from the House of Sarkota. A contingent of mercenaries is being brought into the city as you requested. They will be ready to move on your command.
At last.
1: The message also states that a contact will be arriving shortly to set the last stage in motion.
Did they give a name?
1: Well, that information was not provided, sir. Only that the person would make themselves known to you.
Huh. How typical of Duke Hassa and his people. Paranoid and secretive to the point of idiocy. Still, they have their uses, as this plan will prove.
1: What do we do now?
Pass the word to our agents in every precinct. They all have their assigned targets. They know what to do.
(approaching) Merel? Ah, there you are.
You're dismissed.
1: Er, yes, Lord.
What was that about?
A trivial matter, Magus, a... an obstruction on one of the railways.
Indeed? I trust it'll be removed. It won't do to have the running of our city hindered.
Oh, you may be certain I have the situation in hand.
Good. I've been informed that Ardith has returned from the island. Apparently he has something of great import to discuss. You will join me?

Of course, Magus. If the Argentia's greatest scientician has something to say, I have no doubt it will be worth my time. I confess, I had not expected Ardith to be present for the conclave after his illness. I would have thought him unfit to make the trip.
He insisted on personally escorting the statue here to the citadel.
I'm surprised he was willing to be away from the Heart, even for a day.
His dedication to our cadre is why I chose him. Er, this way. He is waiting on the grand balcony.
If I were Ardith, I'm not sure I'd be so quick to leave the site. From what I've heard, the treasures there are...
You will see it yourself soon enough.
The island is the heart of Argentia, and the legacy of the Mordath.
I know you've made something of a study of it, Merel.

Oh, I merely read the monographs and viewed the film reels. But it occurs to me that our ancestors had some insight when they spoke of the ancient creation myths. The image of the island appears so often in the legends, in the prophecies of our rebirth in a new and shining form.

I would put little stock in the irrational mythology of our primitive forefathers. Our cadre seeks only truth, not superstition. We've grown beyond such things. What the Heart offers us is our true future, based on knowledge, science and advancement.
You're right.
Of course.
Magus Riga. Lord Merel. Excellent. I'm so pleased you could meet with me. I know how busy you must be at this moment.
I have always got time for you, old friend.
Ardith, you seem well.
Just so, just so. My illness is gone, wiped away. I'm hale and hearty. I must thank the Magus for the gift of the Silver. Without it I am certain I would have perished from that Hazelime.
I hope in due course we will do away with every disease just as easily.
Each day at the site I fear we move a little closer toward that ideal. Every new find builds upon the last. We advance by leaps and bounds. And this very week there has been another breakthrough.
A new discovery?
Rather, it would be more accurate to call it a refinement of an old one. See here.
A mechanical cogitator? But it's much smaller than the ones in the Citadel.

Quite so. Most of our computing engines are as large as a dining table. This one is compact enough to be carried on a man's back. It is the latest iteration from our laboratories. Now, do you recognise this object?
A piece of mosaic from the site. It has the characteristic glyphs etched into the surface.
Correct. With this new device we have been able to enhance our translation process and redefine the conversion of these glyphs into our language.
I know these symbols. It says Mordath, the ancient origin myth.
Ah, no. It seems we have been wrong all this time. We translated the word incorrectly. The actual pronunciation is...
Mondas.
Attention, Citizens. This is the Argent City monorail loop-line service, calling at all stations to Ocean Halt.
How long have you been tracking the energy trace?
I didn't come here looking for it. I was just making a stop on my way somewhere.
Mmn, to buy some tea.

Yes. Unfortunately, I landed a bit off-beam, slightly too late. Missed the worst of the civil war though, so that's a good thing. This is a delicate period for any civilisation, you know. New green shoots pushing up through the ashes. What happens now can change the fate of millions for centuries to come.
Doesn't seem like a planet on a battle footing. Look at all those lights and decorations out on the streets. They're celebrating.
They think the war is over, and it is, for them, for the moment. But there are always other wars, aren't there, Temeter?
The energy trace. Would you agree that it's alien? Not native to Tasak, I mean.
It would appear so. Perhaps it's just some intergalactic flotsam. Nothing dangerous at all.
Mmn,, if you believed that you wouldn't still be here.
Tell me about her.
What?
I find the energy trace, I find her. That's what you said. Who is she? Sister? Lover? Victim?
It's not important.
I think it is.
Well, that's all I'm telling you. Unless of course you'd like to be more forthcoming with me, like, say, explaining what that Tardis thing of yours is, or who you work for?
The Tardis travels in Time and Space. I'm just a freelancer, an interested party. I think that about covers it.
I don't believe you.
Well, that's hardly my problem, is it?
Where are we going, anyway?
See the building up ahead? It's the biggest one in this precinct. You can't miss it.
Attention, Citizens. The next station is a restricted stop. Pass-holders only. Security checks are in force. The Grand Citadel of the House of Argentia, next station.
You can't be serious. That is the most fortified place in Argent City, and there's a whole garrison of militia stationed there.

More than that, probably. There's a big do on, you see. Top boffins and high hats from all over the planet, coming together to toast the new peace. I understand that even Magus Riga will be popping along for the wine and cheese.
You're out of your mind if you think you're going to sneak in there, Doctor.
Who said anything about sneaking in? Perish the thought. That'd be against the law.
Attention, Citizens. This is the...

Right. Three men on the gate. If you distract the one on the right, I can deal with the other two. A strike to the nerve cluster on the side of the neck should put them out for two, maybe three hours.
I imagine it would. Hello there! I'm the Doctor!
What are you doing?
2: Hey, that's far enough.
Yes, excellent work. Fine drilling. You're on perfect form, aren't you?
2: Public petitions are taken at the street level entrance. This gate is restricted to pass-holders only.
It certainly is. Here you are.
What's that?
My invitation.
To what?
The Conclave.
2: Oh, I see, Doctor Johannes Smither. Ah well, I'm sorry, sir, I didn't realise. Pardon my sharpness. It's protocol, you see.
Not at all.
2: Who's he?
Him? Oh, er, this is Temeter. He's my plus one.
2: Oh? Stand down. Open the gate.
Too kind.
Would you mind explaining how it is you have an official invitation to enter this building?
The Argentia Conclave is a gathering for the finest scientific minds on this planet. I'm not one to brag, but, well, that does include me.
You stole it, didn't you?
Certainly not!
Hmm.
This isn't my first time on this planet, you know.
This is the Pride of Sarkota calling Argent City Arial Harbour Monitor. Crossing into Metropolitan Zone. Confirm landing authorisation for Argentia Citadel.
(female) Come.
Door opens.
Specialist Etin, you asked to be informed when we entered Argent City airspace.
Oh. Thank you, Trooper. What's the status of the... the cargo?
They're secure on the sealed decks, Ma'am. Even if the enemy put inspectors aboard, they'll find nothing. The compartments are well-concealed.
The Sarkota signed the peace accord along with every other noble House. The Argentia are not our enemy, Trooper, not any more.
If that's so, Ma'am, then why are we here? Why are we doing this?
I've been asking myself that question ever since we left the capital. You'd think our taste for bloodshed would lessen after so much of it.
The Argentia brought this on themselves. They're the ones telling everyone else what to do, trying to put all of Tasak under their flag.
But we agreed to put down our arms. The mission we have embarked on here might be seen as dishonourable in light of that fact.
We have our orders.

Yes we do. From the lips of our cadre master Duke Hassa himself, and we will obey them. We will help this man Merel with his plan. Have the men load their weapons and make ready for deployment at a moment's notice. And just in case some nosey Argentia does spot them...
No prisoners?
And no traces.
Concert music in background.
Wooff! Impressive. These people like their spectacle.
Well, if you're fond of steel and glass and marble, yes. It's all a bit sterile, if you ask me.
We shouldn't waste any time. We should scan...
Put that scanner away before someone sees it. Look.
Dido! I couldn't agree more...
There's the man of the hour.
Lord of the House of Argentia. I thought he'd be taller.
It'd be rude not to say hello, don't you think?
Wait, Doctor, wait!
... This cord still holds strong.
This conclave is a validation of Tasak's new unity.
Yes.
A year ago the idea of bringing our world's leading scienticians together under one roof would've been greeted with derision.
And who do we have to thank for that?
The House of Argentia does not seek a claim for its deeds. A secure future for our people is more than enough.
Well said. Well said indeed. Brought Tasak back from the brink of destruction. You should be proud, Mister, er...?
Jorrow Ardith, Chief Scientician of the House Argentia. And you are...?
The Doctor. House, er, Gallifrey.
Gallifrey? Pardon me, but the name is unfamiliar.
That's quite all right, Magus Riga. We're a small group. Quite exclusive.
Mmm, very small.
I must say - and you'll forgive me if I sound churlish, but - it is quite incredible how you've managed to accomplish so much in so short a time.
I disagree, Doctor. The direct application of intellect and the gifts of the Argentia, are all that was required to bring stability to our world.
Gifts?
Cogitators, machines, new engines. Our panacea of drugs alone have revolutionised medicine across the planet.
Many lives have been saved from the benefits of the Silver.
The Silver?
A curative compound, Doctor. I'm surprised you're not familiar with it. We made it widely available in recent months.
Oh, of course. My apologies. I must seem dreadfully provincial. Still, so many advances so quickly. We should be thankful that your intentions are wholly altruistic.
We have made peace, Doctor, with every House that opposed us, even our age-old rivals in the Sarkota. After all, what good is knowledge if you cannot share it for the betterment of all?
I agree. It's nice to meet someone like-minded for a change.
Indeed. Tasak is our world, the cradle of our civilisation. We must protect it.
But if the war is over, who are you protecting it from? Aliens? Off-worlders?
Other worlds would find nothing of interest here. I imagine they would consider all of us to be dreadfully provincial, eh Doctor?
Quite.
I'm not so sure. What if...?
Magus, my Lords and Lady. I was not aware we had new arrivals.
Merel, this is the Doctor and his companion...?
Temeter.
Of the House of Gallifrey. We were having a most intriguing conversation.
I overheard a little of it, yes. Doctor, I wonder. Might I borrow you for a moment?
Of course. Magus, Ardith, if you'll excuse me?
Perhaps we'll speak again later.
I look forward to it. Come along, Temeter.
(sotto) I'm a side-kick now, am I?
Peculiar young man.
Door opens.
Mmm. Lovely view from out here.
Door closes.
Are you some sort of fool?
Some sort, possibly.
What do you think you're doing, speaking openly about off-worlders?
What? What do you know about...?
Duke Hassa was given that information in the strictest confidence.
Clearly we were remiss. I apologise.
I don't want an apology, I want discretion. And what kind of sham was that? The House of Gallifrey? Couldn't you come up with something that isn't obviously a fake name?
It seemed real enough to me.
You should have come to me first, not test your luck with Riga. Those were my orders. If the Sarkota cannot follow simple instructions then this operation will not succeed.
Of course. And we can't have that, can we?
No.
But Hassa is very interested in this off-worlder. We only wanted to learn more about her.
I'll keep my end of the bargain. Hassa will be allowed to interrogate the woman once the operation is complete.
Where is she?
Safe.
That's not what we've been told. Frankly, the Duke has his doubts you even have her at all.
He questions my word? She's in this very building.
I need to see her.
Yes, we need to see her, to... verify her condition. Proof of life and all that.
That was not part of the plan.
Plans change. You need to be flexible, Merel, if you expect success.
If I leave the reception without good reason, Riga will become suspicious.
Then tell us where she is. We'll take a look and come right back, won't we?
Oh yes.
Riga won't suspect a thing.
Very well. Go to the 95th tier. When you return, we will discuss the deployment of the troopers. Time is of the essence.
More than you know.
Sara's here.
Oh dear. That's what happens when you jump to conclusions. He'll kick himself when he finds out.
Merel's mistaken you for someone else.
I seem to have a face for it.
I wonder who he thinks we are?
I'd rather not stick around and find out.
He was talking about the Sarkota, their, former enemies. I am not letting them interrogate her.
Sara, eh? Well, a good lie usually has about ten or so minutes of life in it, so we should probably get a move on. Come on. This way up.
[OC]: Halt. This level is off-limits.
[OC]: Merel sent us, to see the woman.
[OC]: I'll need to get authorisation.
What's going on out there?
[OC]: We don't have time for this.
Thump, thud, door opens.
You didn't have to hit him.
Who are you?
You're right. I didn't have to.
Temeter!
Moment of truth.
Sara, I thought I'd never see you again.
I knew. I knew you'd come. (kiss)
It's all right. You're safe now.
Actually...
Who's this? Not a local. An Earther?
No, I don't think so. It's a long story.
Then tell me.
While I hate to interrupt this touching moment, I must point out that we don't have time to stop and chat.
It won't take a second. Connect?
Yes of course. Connecting.
Burble of data.
You're an android. You're both androids.
Transfer complete. I agree, he isn't a human. And that Tardis...
We'll worry about that later. The mission, yes?
Yes, we have to go.
What else are you keeping from me?
Funny. I was just thinking the same thing about you.
Lord Merel? I would speak with you.
I'm in no mood for idle conversation, madam. Kindly find your diversions elsewhere.
I think not. Unless you wish Duke Hassa to take back his men and let you prosecute your insurrection alone?
What?
I see the Argentians' reputation for arrogance is well-deserved.
You are the contact from Sarkota? Bult...
Of course. What did you expect? Code-words and disguises? I'm a scientician. I have little tolerance for such parlour games.
Then who's the Doctor?
I have no idea what you are referring to.
Guards! With me, quickly!
Central Command were correct. There is alien technology on Tasak. I found proof.
Where?
The island, a few kilometres off the coast of Argent City. It's a dig site.
They call it the Heart. Apparently there's some significance regarding it in the local legends.
But they captured you before you could get out there. Riga found your equipment.
He guessed from that I was an off-worlder, but he wasn't aware that I am...
A synthetic being?
An android, Doctor.
The Magus has been holding me for months trying to convince me to help them.
This way. There's a lift down there.
But he didn't try to compel you through force? I mean, he didn't hurt you?
No, but I know Merel has different ideas. I've seen this in his eyes.
If we can reach the upper tiers, take the coleopter...
That's far enough, Doctor. Another step and you'll be gunned down.
Shift it up. Shoot to live.
Ah. Did I say ten minutes? More like five.
There's a forty seven per cent chance we could neutralise all the guards before they inflicted a critical level of damage upon us.
Bad odds. I have a better idea.
And that is...?
Don't shoot! We surrender! Take me... take me to your leader.
[PA]: It is my privilege to welcome all of you here to the citadel of my cadre. You of the noble Houses of Tasak.
Applause.
Bravo. Hear, hear.

[PA]: I'm greatly pleased to see Specialist Etin and her party from the House of Sarkota here as honoured guests. The bad blood and feuding between our cadres is at last put behind us in the name of a new future. I welcome you to Argent City, and in that spirit, I wish to present a gift to our former adversaries. A piece of the Heart. A relic of the Argentia. My adjutant Lord Merel... (sotto) Er, where is he?
Magus, there appears to have been a security breach on the upper tiers.
What sort of breach? The statue...
Is untouched. It's the woman. The off-worlder.
Is he over there?
Forgive this interruption, Magus, but I have discovered a conspiracy among our guests. This man...
Good evening!
This man is a spy. He and his associate attempted to free this dangerous alien terrorist.
Terrorist?
Doctor, I'm disappointed to learn you deceived me.
There's a lot of it about. Sorry.
I knew it. I knew there was something odd about him.

I see. [PA] But I refuse to allow this to overshadow this day's auspicious gathering. In the face of such actions I find my resolve strengthened still further to strive towards a peaceful unity among all Houses.
Smattering of applause.

[PA]: Madam Etin, in the name of peace and friendship, I offer you and the Sarkota this artefact. A relic unearthed from the Heart. A symbol of a past we have left behind, and the future we hope to forge. Merel?
[PA]: A statue, carved from steel.
No.
That's not a statue.
It's a Cyberman.

parts.searchable_dialogue:
SARA: Almost time.
SARA: Why do you bother to knock?
RIGA: Hello, Sara. I hope the day finds you well.
SARA: When are you going to release me?
RIGA: I've been told that you're eating very little. Are you unwell?
SARA: There are guards outside?
RIGA: Regrettably, yes. I wish it were not necessary.
SARA: At last we agree on something.
RIGA: That is progress, then, of a sort. Will you share a cup of tea with me? No? No. This is one of the planet's finest blends. Tasak has so much to offer if only you would open yourself to it. As a guest of the Argentia...
SARA: A guest? What's wrong, Magus Riga? Does the word prisoner stick in your throat?
RIGA: You are not a captive, my dear.
SARA: You hold me here in this gilded cage, I'm not allowed to leave...
RIGA: These apartments are among the most lavish in Argent City. Your every need is provided for. We have been excellent hosts.
SARA: I didn't ask for your... hospitality.
RIGA: You are being protected, Sara. As an off-worlder you are... valuable. Your knowledge is a potential wellspring of power. Can you not understand that? Will you join us? If I must beg you, I will. Please, Sara, join our cadre, help us guide our planet towards a new shining future. Look. (opens window) Down there. Our city swells with new arrivals every day, refugees displaced by the conflicts, the desperate and the hopeful, drawn here from all across Tasak. They look to the House of Argentia, to my cadre, for stewardship. We ended the war, Sara. Now it is our burden is to begin the peace. Help me to do that.
SARA: I will never help you with the Heart.
RIGA: It is our way forward.
SARA: You're tampering with something beyond your comprehension. It will destroy you. Don't you understand, Riga? You're threatening the lives of every living being on this planet.
RIGA: That is not true. I would never place my people in harm's way.
SARA: Listen to me! I'm trying to warn you.
RIGA: You're becoming agitated. I apologise. I did not mean to provoke you. (closes window) Perhaps it would be best if I left.
SARA: Riga, I can't help you.
RIGA: Then I will make the offer again next week, and if need be the week after, and the week after that, as I have for these three months past, until you see we have only good intentions.
RIGA: Until you say yes.
RIGA: Guard, send for a kitchen servitor. Perhaps the food is not to her liking. It will not do for her to starve herself.
GUARD: As you order, Magus.
MEREL: And what if she doesn't eat? What then? Forgive me, Magus, but we indulge the off-worlder too much.
RIGA: And what would you have me do, Merel? What would you do if you were Magus?
MEREL: Respecttully, I believe a more aggressive approach would be expedient.
RIGA: We will not compel her by force.
MEREL: I only draw your attention toward an alternative.
RIGA: Sara must join the House of Argentia of her own free will, or else our values mean nothing. Freedom of choice is the cornerstone of our cadre's principles. I will never allow that to be subverted. Is that clear?
MEREL: Of course, sir. I did not mean to imply otherwise.
RIGA: How are preparations for the Great Conclave progressing?
MEREL: As planned. The delegates from the other Houses have been arriving all through the morning.
RIGA: Gathering the greatest minds of every noble cadre. And the future, there ahead of us, close enough to touch.
MEREL: The last ship will land just after second sunset.
RIGA: The deputation from the House of Sarkota?
MEREL: Of course.
RIGA: Of course. They would never allow themselves to be the first to arrive, would they? That might smack of capitulation, weakness. How unhappy they must be without war.
MEREL: I suppose so.
RIGA: If we do this right, Merel, there will never need to be a war again. We will banish famine and disease, wipe out poverty. All our tomorrows, not just those of the Argentia or the Sarkota, they turn upon this moment. When we reveal the secrets of the Heart, we will take charge of the destiny of our world. Tasak will be forever changed.
MEREL: Yes. Yes. I believe it will.
TEMETER: Recording. Mission file, day 20. I've tracked the energy trace to Argent City, a conurbation on the northern coast of the central continent. The trace is intermittent. I can't triangulate it yet, but I'm sure the target's here. She must have found it. (beeps) How? How could...? Mission File, additional. I have an anomaly There's a second trace here. It doesn't match any known aggressor profiles or the primary target. Far too advanced for the local tech, maybe even more advanced than ours. It's close. I'm going to investigate.
DOCTOR: Careful not to sear the leaves. It’s quite a delicate plant. Ah. Just in time for a visitor.
TEMETER: [OC]: Recording. The source of the new trace appears to be some sort of blue shed.
DOCTOR: Huh. Charming.
TEMETER: [OC]: The door, it's opening. I'm proceeding inside the construction.
TEMETER: It's ... that's...
DOCTOR: Rude of you. To come in without knocking, I mean.
TEMETER: Who are you? What is this place?
DOCTOR: I'm the Doctor, this is the Tardis. Your turn.
TEMETER: Oh no, I'm not answering any questions from a man holding a weapon on me.
DOCTOR: This? Oh, I suppose it does appear rather dangerous from a certain point of view, doesn't it? Hmm. And I can see from your expression that you've had guns pointed at you before. You're not afraid. Careful but wary. A career soldier, perhaps? I know your kind quite well.
TEMETER: What is that thing, a thermal blaster? Do your worst, you'll get nothing from me.
DOCTOR: Oh, I beg to differ. Let's have a look at you. Hmm. At first glance you seem like a, a local, but your clothes are cut too well and your teeth? Huh, they're a dead giveaway. Far too clean for someone from a pre-atomic industrial revolution era society.
TEMETER: You're an outsider yourself.
DOCTOR: Everywhere I go. And then, there's that scanner you're trying to conceal in your pocket. I don't imagine Tasak science will be able to come up with something like that for a few centuries. Hand it over.
TEMETER: You're a human. From Earth?
DOCTOR: I can see you might think that. (beep) Interesting. Military issue. This sort of hardware was quite common during the Orion War period.
TEMETER: Was?
DOCTOR: Oh yes, well, pardon my tenses. Is. You're a covert agent, yes? Both sides deployed thousands of operatives like you during the war.
TEMETER: And whose side are you on, Doctor?
DOCTOR: But that doesn't explain why you're on Tasak, does it? We're light years away from the battle lines of the Orion War. What are you doing on a backwater steam-age planet far away from your nasty little war?
TEMETER: Why are you here?
DOCTOR: Me? Oh. For the tea. Care for a cup? It's really very good. Best in the quadrant.
TEMETER: That's... not a weapon.
DOCTOR: I never said it was. It's a self-heating fusion teapot. Easy mistake to make, though. Biscuit, Mister, er...?
TEMETER: Temeter. My name is Temeter, and, er - no. No thank you.
DOCTOR: There. Now we're being much more civilised. I should apologise, actually.
TEMETER: For what?
DOCTOR: This reading. (beeping) The one that drew you here. A deliberate fiction on my part. The Tardis picked up the output from your scans of the city. I wanted to learn who was behind them. I left some cheese in the mousetrap, as it were.
TEMETER: You generated the second energy trace?
DOCTOR: Yes. The second. But not the first. That one is quite a puzzle.
TEMETER: Do you know what it is?
DOCTOR: Not yet. There's too much phase-wave interference. That's very unusual for such a low-tech civilisation.
TEMETER: I agree. But for a moment I thought it was...
DOCTOR: Thought it was what? I'm sorry to disappoint you.
TEMETER: Disappoint me?
DOCTOR: This energy trace isn't all you're looking for, is it?
TEMETER: I'm searching for... someone. I find the energy trace, I find her.
DOCTOR: Perhaps we ought to pool our resources. Two heads, and so on.
TEMETER: Or not. No offence, Doctor, but it'll take more than tea and a biscuit to win me over.
DOCTOR: You'll find me quite agreeable once you get to know me.
TEMETER: Hmm. Maybe I should let you stick close. Just to keep an eye on you.
DOCTOR: Funny. I was just thinking the same thing about you.
GUARD: 1: Lord Merel, I have the communiqué from the House of...
MEREL: Well, don't announce it to everyone in the citadel. Speak.
GUARD: 1: I have the communiqué from the House of Sarkota. A contingent of mercenaries is being brought into the city as you requested. They will be ready to move on your command.
MEREL: At last.
GUARD: 1: The message also states that a contact will be arriving shortly to set the last stage in motion.
MEREL: Did they give a name?
GUARD: 1: Well, that information was not provided, sir. Only that the person would make themselves known to you.
MEREL: Huh. How typical of Duke Hassa and his people. Paranoid and secretive to the point of idiocy. Still, they have their uses, as this plan will prove.
GUARD: 1: What do we do now?
MEREL: Pass the word to our agents in every precinct. They all have their assigned targets. They know what to do.
RIGA: (approaching) Merel? Ah, there you are.
MEREL: You're dismissed.
GUARD: 1: Er, yes, Lord.
RIGA: What was that about?
MEREL: A trivial matter, Magus, a... an obstruction on one of the railways.
RIGA: Indeed? I trust it'll be removed. It won't do to have the running of our city hindered.
MEREL: Oh, you may be certain I have the situation in hand.
RIGA: Good. I've been informed that Ardith has returned from the island. Apparently he has something of great import to discuss. You will join me?
MEREL: Of course, Magus. If the Argentia's greatest scientician has something to say, I have no doubt it will be worth my time. I confess, I had not expected Ardith to be present for the conclave after his illness. I would have thought him unfit to make the trip.
RIGA: He insisted on personally escorting the statue here to the citadel.
MEREL: I'm surprised he was willing to be away from the Heart, even for a day.
RIGA: His dedication to our cadre is why I chose him. Er, this way. He is waiting on the grand balcony.
MEREL: If I were Ardith, I'm not sure I'd be so quick to leave the site. From what I've heard, the treasures there are...
RIGA: You will see it yourself soon enough.
MEREL: The island is the heart of Argentia, and the legacy of the Mordath.
RIGA: I know you've made something of a study of it, Merel.
MEREL: Oh, I merely read the monographs and viewed the film reels. But it occurs to me that our ancestors had some insight when they spoke of the ancient creation myths. The image of the island appears so often in the legends, in the prophecies of our rebirth in a new and shining form.
RIGA: I would put little stock in the irrational mythology of our primitive forefathers. Our cadre seeks only truth, not superstition. We've grown beyond such things. What the Heart offers us is our true future, based on knowledge, science and advancement.
MEREL: You're right.
RIGA: Of course.
ARDITH: Magus Riga. Lord Merel. Excellent. I'm so pleased you could meet with me. I know how busy you must be at this moment.
RIGA: I have always got time for you, old friend.
MEREL: Ardith, you seem well.
ARDITH: Just so, just so. My illness is gone, wiped away. I'm hale and hearty. I must thank the Magus for the gift of the Silver. Without it I am certain I would have perished from that Hazelime.
RIGA: I hope in due course we will do away with every disease just as easily.
ARDITH: Each day at the site I fear we move a little closer toward that ideal. Every new find builds upon the last. We advance by leaps and bounds. And this very week there has been another breakthrough.
MEREL: A new discovery?
ARDITH: Rather, it would be more accurate to call it a refinement of an old one. See here.
RIGA: A mechanical cogitator? But it's much smaller than the ones in the Citadel.
ARDITH: Quite so. Most of our computing engines are as large as a dining table. This one is compact enough to be carried on a man's back. It is the latest iteration from our laboratories. Now, do you recognise this object?
MEREL: A piece of mosaic from the site. It has the characteristic glyphs etched into the surface.
ARDITH: Correct. With this new device we have been able to enhance our translation process and redefine the conversion of these glyphs into our language.
MEREL: I know these symbols. It says Mordath, the ancient origin myth.
ARDITH: Ah, no. It seems we have been wrong all this time. We translated the word incorrectly. The actual pronunciation is...
RIGA: Mondas.
TANNOY: Attention, Citizens. This is the Argent City monorail loop-line service, calling at all stations to Ocean Halt.
TEMETER: How long have you been tracking the energy trace?
DOCTOR: I didn't come here looking for it. I was just making a stop on my way somewhere.
TEMETER: Mmn, to buy some tea.
DOCTOR: Yes. Unfortunately, I landed a bit off-beam, slightly too late. Missed the worst of the civil war though, so that's a good thing. This is a delicate period for any civilisation, you know. New green shoots pushing up through the ashes. What happens now can change the fate of millions for centuries to come.
TEMETER: Doesn't seem like a planet on a battle footing. Look at all those lights and decorations out on the streets. They're celebrating.
DOCTOR: They think the war is over, and it is, for them, for the moment. But there are always other wars, aren't there, Temeter?
TEMETER: The energy trace. Would you agree that it's alien? Not native to Tasak, I mean.
DOCTOR: It would appear so. Perhaps it's just some intergalactic flotsam. Nothing dangerous at all.
TEMETER: Mmn,, if you believed that you wouldn't still be here.
DOCTOR: Tell me about her.
TEMETER: What?
DOCTOR: I find the energy trace, I find her. That's what you said. Who is she? Sister? Lover? Victim?
TEMETER: It's not important.
DOCTOR: I think it is.
TEMETER: Well, that's all I'm telling you. Unless of course you'd like to be more forthcoming with me, like, say, explaining what that Tardis thing of yours is, or who you work for?
DOCTOR: The Tardis travels in Time and Space. I'm just a freelancer, an interested party. I think that about covers it.
TEMETER: I don't believe you.
DOCTOR: Well, that's hardly my problem, is it?
TEMETER: Where are we going, anyway?
DOCTOR: See the building up ahead? It's the biggest one in this precinct. You can't miss it.
TANNOY: Attention, Citizens. The next station is a restricted stop. Pass-holders only. Security checks are in force. The Grand Citadel of the House of Argentia, next station.
TEMETER: You can't be serious. That is the most fortified place in Argent City, and there's a whole garrison of militia stationed there.
DOCTOR: More than that, probably. There's a big do on, you see. Top boffins and high hats from all over the planet, coming together to toast the new peace. I understand that even Magus Riga will be popping along for the wine and cheese.
TEMETER: You're out of your mind if you think you're going to sneak in there, Doctor.
DOCTOR: Who said anything about sneaking in? Perish the thought. That'd be against the law.
TANNOY: Attention, Citizens. This is the...
TEMETER: Right. Three men on the gate. If you distract the one on the right, I can deal with the other two. A strike to the nerve cluster on the side of the neck should put them out for two, maybe three hours.
DOCTOR: I imagine it would. Hello there! I'm the Doctor!
TEMETER: What are you doing?
GUARD: 2: Hey, that's far enough.
DOCTOR: Yes, excellent work. Fine drilling. You're on perfect form, aren't you?
GUARD: 2: Public petitions are taken at the street level entrance. This gate is restricted to pass-holders only.
DOCTOR: It certainly is. Here you are.
TEMETER: What's that?
DOCTOR: My invitation.
TEMETER: To what?
DOCTOR: The Conclave.
GUARD: 2: Oh, I see, Doctor Johannes Smither. Ah well, I'm sorry, sir, I didn't realise. Pardon my sharpness. It's protocol, you see.
DOCTOR: Not at all.
GUARD: 2: Who's he?
DOCTOR: Him? Oh, er, this is Temeter. He's my plus one.
GUARD: 2: Oh? Stand down. Open the gate.
DOCTOR: Too kind.
TEMETER: Would you mind explaining how it is you have an official invitation to enter this building?
DOCTOR: The Argentia Conclave is a gathering for the finest scientific minds on this planet. I'm not one to brag, but, well, that does include me.
TEMETER: You stole it, didn't you?
DOCTOR: Certainly not!
TEMETER: Hmm.
DOCTOR: This isn't my first time on this planet, you know.
PILOT: This is the Pride of Sarkota calling Argent City Arial Harbour Monitor. Crossing into Metropolitan Zone. Confirm landing authorisation for Argentia Citadel.
ETIN: (female) Come.
TROOPER: Specialist Etin, you asked to be informed when we entered Argent City airspace.
ETIN: Oh. Thank you, Trooper. What's the status of the... the cargo?
TROOPER: They're secure on the sealed decks, Ma'am. Even if the enemy put inspectors aboard, they'll find nothing. The compartments are well-concealed.
ETIN: The Sarkota signed the peace accord along with every other noble House. The Argentia are not our enemy, Trooper, not any more.
TROOPER: If that's so, Ma'am, then why are we here? Why are we doing this?
ETIN: I've been asking myself that question ever since we left the capital. You'd think our taste for bloodshed would lessen after so much of it.
TROOPER: The Argentia brought this on themselves. They're the ones telling everyone else what to do, trying to put all of Tasak under their flag.
ETIN: But we agreed to put down our arms. The mission we have embarked on here might be seen as dishonourable in light of that fact.
TROOPER: We have our orders.
ETIN: Yes we do. From the lips of our cadre master Duke Hassa himself, and we will obey them. We will help this man Merel with his plan. Have the men load their weapons and make ready for deployment at a moment's notice. And just in case some nosey Argentia does spot them...
TROOPER: No prisoners?
ETIN: And no traces.
TEMETER: Wooff! Impressive. These people like their spectacle.
DOCTOR: Well, if you're fond of steel and glass and marble, yes. It's all a bit sterile, if you ask me.
TEMETER: We shouldn't waste any time. We should scan...
DOCTOR: Put that scanner away before someone sees it. Look.
RIGA: Dido! I couldn't agree more...
DOCTOR: There's the man of the hour.
RIGA: Lord of the House of Argentia. I thought he'd be taller.
DOCTOR: It'd be rude not to say hello, don't you think?
TEMETER: Wait, Doctor, wait!
RIGA: ... This cord still holds strong.
ARDITH: This conclave is a validation of Tasak's new unity.
RIGA: Yes.
ARDITH: A year ago the idea of bringing our world's leading scienticians together under one roof would've been greeted with derision.
DOCTOR: And who do we have to thank for that?
ARDITH: The House of Argentia does not seek a claim for its deeds. A secure future for our people is more than enough.
DOCTOR: Well said. Well said indeed. Brought Tasak back from the brink of destruction. You should be proud, Mister, er...?
ARDITH: Jorrow Ardith, Chief Scientician of the House Argentia. And you are...?
DOCTOR: The Doctor. House, er, Gallifrey.
RIGA: Gallifrey? Pardon me, but the name is unfamiliar.
DOCTOR: That's quite all right, Magus Riga. We're a small group. Quite exclusive.
TEMETER: Mmm, very small.
DOCTOR: I must say - and you'll forgive me if I sound churlish, but - it is quite incredible how you've managed to accomplish so much in so short a time.
ARDITH: I disagree, Doctor. The direct application of intellect and the gifts of the Argentia, are all that was required to bring stability to our world.
TEMETER: Gifts?
ARDITH: Cogitators, machines, new engines. Our panacea of drugs alone have revolutionised medicine across the planet.
RIGA: Many lives have been saved from the benefits of the Silver.
DOCTOR: The Silver?
RIGA: A curative compound, Doctor. I'm surprised you're not familiar with it. We made it widely available in recent months.
DOCTOR: Oh, of course. My apologies. I must seem dreadfully provincial. Still, so many advances so quickly. We should be thankful that your intentions are wholly altruistic.
RIGA: We have made peace, Doctor, with every House that opposed us, even our age-old rivals in the Sarkota. After all, what good is knowledge if you cannot share it for the betterment of all?
DOCTOR: I agree. It's nice to meet someone like-minded for a change.
RIGA: Indeed. Tasak is our world, the cradle of our civilisation. We must protect it.
TEMETER: But if the war is over, who are you protecting it from? Aliens? Off-worlders?
RIGA: Other worlds would find nothing of interest here. I imagine they would consider all of us to be dreadfully provincial, eh Doctor?
DOCTOR: Quite.
TEMETER: I'm not so sure. What if...?
MEREL: Magus, my Lords and Lady. I was not aware we had new arrivals.
ARDITH: Merel, this is the Doctor and his companion...?
DOCTOR: Temeter.
RIGA: Of the House of Gallifrey. We were having a most intriguing conversation.
MEREL: I overheard a little of it, yes. Doctor, I wonder. Might I borrow you for a moment?
DOCTOR: Of course. Magus, Ardith, if you'll excuse me?
RIGA: Perhaps we'll speak again later.
DOCTOR: I look forward to it. Come along, Temeter.
TEMETER: (sotto) I'm a side-kick now, am I?
ARDITH: Peculiar young man.
DOCTOR: Mmm. Lovely view from out here.
MEREL: Are you some sort of fool?
DOCTOR: Some sort, possibly.
MEREL: What do you think you're doing, speaking openly about off-worlders?
TEMETER: What? What do you know about...?
MEREL: Duke Hassa was given that information in the strictest confidence.
DOCTOR: Clearly we were remiss. I apologise.
MEREL: I don't want an apology, I want discretion. And what kind of sham was that? The House of Gallifrey? Couldn't you come up with something that isn't obviously a fake name?
DOCTOR: It seemed real enough to me.
MEREL: You should have come to me first, not test your luck with Riga. Those were my orders. If the Sarkota cannot follow simple instructions then this operation will not succeed.
DOCTOR: Of course. And we can't have that, can we?
TEMETER: No.
DOCTOR: But Hassa is very interested in this off-worlder. We only wanted to learn more about her.
MEREL: I'll keep my end of the bargain. Hassa will be allowed to interrogate the woman once the operation is complete.
TEMETER: Where is she?
MEREL: Safe.
DOCTOR: That's not what we've been told. Frankly, the Duke has his doubts you even have her at all.
MEREL: He questions my word? She's in this very building.
TEMETER: I need to see her.
DOCTOR: Yes, we need to see her, to... verify her condition. Proof of life and all that.
MEREL: That was not part of the plan.
DOCTOR: Plans change. You need to be flexible, Merel, if you expect success.
MEREL: If I leave the reception without good reason, Riga will become suspicious.
DOCTOR: Then tell us where she is. We'll take a look and come right back, won't we?
TEMETER: Oh yes.
DOCTOR: Riga won't suspect a thing.
MEREL: Very well. Go to the 95th tier. When you return, we will discuss the deployment of the troopers. Time is of the essence.
DOCTOR: More than you know.
TEMETER: Sara's here.
DOCTOR: Oh dear. That's what happens when you jump to conclusions. He'll kick himself when he finds out.
TEMETER: Merel's mistaken you for someone else.
DOCTOR: I seem to have a face for it.
TEMETER: I wonder who he thinks we are?
DOCTOR: I'd rather not stick around and find out.
TEMETER: He was talking about the Sarkota, their, former enemies. I am not letting them interrogate her.
DOCTOR: Sara, eh? Well, a good lie usually has about ten or so minutes of life in it, so we should probably get a move on. Come on. This way up.
GUARD: [OC]: Halt. This level is off-limits.
DOCTOR: [OC]: Merel sent us, to see the woman.
GUARD: [OC]: I'll need to get authorisation.
SARA: What's going on out there?
TEMETER: [OC]: We don't have time for this.
DOCTOR: You didn't have to hit him.
SARA: Who are you?
TEMETER: You're right. I didn't have to.
SARA: Temeter!
DOCTOR: Moment of truth.
TEMETER: Sara, I thought I'd never see you again.
SARA: I knew. I knew you'd come. (kiss)
TEMETER: It's all right. You're safe now.
DOCTOR: Actually...
SARA: Who's this? Not a local. An Earther?
TEMETER: No, I don't think so. It's a long story.
SARA: Then tell me.
DOCTOR: While I hate to interrupt this touching moment, I must point out that we don't have time to stop and chat.
TEMETER: It won't take a second. Connect?
SARA: Yes of course. Connecting.
DOCTOR: You're an android. You're both androids.
SARA: Transfer complete. I agree, he isn't a human. And that Tardis...
TEMETER: We'll worry about that later. The mission, yes?
SARA: Yes, we have to go.
DOCTOR: What else are you keeping from me?
TEMETER: Funny. I was just thinking the same thing about you.
ETIN: Lord Merel? I would speak with you.
MEREL: I'm in no mood for idle conversation, madam. Kindly find your diversions elsewhere.
ETIN: I think not. Unless you wish Duke Hassa to take back his men and let you prosecute your insurrection alone?
MEREL: What?
ETIN: I see the Argentians' reputation for arrogance is well-deserved.
MEREL: You are the contact from Sarkota? Bult...
ETIN: Of course. What did you expect? Code-words and disguises? I'm a scientician. I have little tolerance for such parlour games.
MEREL: Then who's the Doctor?
ETIN: I have no idea what you are referring to.
MEREL: Guards! With me, quickly!
SARA: Central Command were correct. There is alien technology on Tasak. I found proof.
DOCTOR: Where?
TEMETER: The island, a few kilometres off the coast of Argent City. It's a dig site.
SARA: They call it the Heart. Apparently there's some significance regarding it in the local legends.
TEMETER: But they captured you before you could get out there. Riga found your equipment.
SARA: He guessed from that I was an off-worlder, but he wasn't aware that I am...
DOCTOR: A synthetic being?
TEMETER: An android, Doctor.
SARA: The Magus has been holding me for months trying to convince me to help them.
TEMETER: This way. There's a lift down there.
DOCTOR: But he didn't try to compel you through force? I mean, he didn't hurt you?
SARA: No, but I know Merel has different ideas. I've seen this in his eyes.
TEMETER: If we can reach the upper tiers, take the coleopter...
MEREL: That's far enough, Doctor. Another step and you'll be gunned down.
MAN: Shift it up. Shoot to live.
DOCTOR: Ah. Did I say ten minutes? More like five.
TEMETER: There's a forty seven per cent chance we could neutralise all the guards before they inflicted a critical level of damage upon us.
DOCTOR: Bad odds. I have a better idea.
SARA: And that is...?
DOCTOR: Don't shoot! We surrender! Take me... take me to your leader.
RIGA: [PA]: It is my privilege to welcome all of you here to the citadel of my cadre. You of the noble Houses of Tasak.
MEN: Bravo. Hear, hear.
RIGA: [PA]: I'm greatly pleased to see Specialist Etin and her party from the House of Sarkota here as honoured guests. The bad blood and feuding between our cadres is at last put behind us in the name of a new future. I welcome you to Argent City, and in that spirit, I wish to present a gift to our former adversaries. A piece of the Heart. A relic of the Argentia. My adjutant Lord Merel... (sotto) Er, where is he?
ARDITH: Magus, there appears to have been a security breach on the upper tiers.
RIGA: What sort of breach? The statue...
ARDITH: Is untouched. It's the woman. The off-worlder.
WOMAN: Is he over there?
MEREL: Forgive this interruption, Magus, but I have discovered a conspiracy among our guests. This man...
DOCTOR: Good evening!
MEREL: This man is a spy. He and his associate attempted to free this dangerous alien terrorist.
TEMETER: Terrorist?
RIGA: Doctor, I'm disappointed to learn you deceived me.
DOCTOR: There's a lot of it about. Sorry.
ARDITH: I knew it. I knew there was something odd about him.
RIGA: I see. [PA] But I refuse to allow this to overshadow this day's auspicious gathering. In the face of such actions I find my resolve strengthened still further to strive towards a peaceful unity among all Houses.
RIGA: [PA]: Madam Etin, in the name of peace and friendship, I offer you and the Sarkota this artefact. A relic unearthed from the Heart. A symbol of a past we have left behind, and the future we hope to forge. Merel?
MEREL: [PA]: A statue, carved from steel.
DOCTOR: No.
TEMETER: That's not a statue.
DOCTOR: It's a Cyberman.

elements.text: [Part Two]
What does that word mean?
It means an end to all life on this planet. Those energy traces. Cyber-technology. This is what we were tracking.
What is this impostor babbling about? Guards, how did he ever even get in here? Guards! Put these people in confinement.
Yes. Take them away.
Wait. You have to listen to me, all of you. If that Cyberman becomes active...
Why should we listen to a single word you say?
Because he's right. You wanted me to help you. Well, I'm helping you now. This is what I was hiding from you.

So you knew? (loud) Listen to me, all of you! Your planet is contaminated with alien mechanisms. War machines designed only for killing and conquest. This technology is more deadly than anything in your experience.
He's a militant. One of the separatist rabble. This is clearly some foolish attempt to disrupt the Conclave and destroy any chance of unity.
Oh, there'll be unity all right, if you let these things loose on Tasak. A unity without emotion, without life!
Magus, a word?
Speak, Merel, and quickly before this farce ruins the moment.
These men. If they're like the woman...
Off-worlders.
The knowledge they have could be considerable. This Doctor, he clearly has some insight.
What do you suggest?
We should keep them close at hand. They could prove useful.
What about his warning?
Clearly the aliens are afraid of us. But we cannot let that stand in our way.
No, we cannot. (loud) Secure the Doctor and his accomplices aboard the coleopter.
You're making a terrible mistake!
Pride of Sarkota exiting Argent City zone. Set heading blue green six decimal. Wind correction factor eight. On course for coastal islands.
Temeter, sit down. You've been pacing all night.
The suns are coming up. The guards will probably check in on us soon. We should make our move then.
And do what? We're over the ocean.
We could survive the fall. Not so sure about you, though.
We can't leave the Doctor behind.
Of course you can. You didn't see fit to include me up to this point.
Oh, trust must be a very abundant commodity where you're from, Doctor. I won't apologise for keeping my secrets from a complete stranger, from a man obviously in the employ of the Earth military.
I'm anything but that.
What else could you be then, huh? Some interstellar do-gooder meddling just for the fun of it?
Temeter.
No, no, no, he's quite right. I mean, why should you trust me? Why should you even bother to mention that there were Cybermen on Tasak?

Our observer probes discovered cultural indicators in their mythology, suggestions of an intervention far back in the history. Great beings. A prophecy of them merging with their deities. Something that left a mark on Tasak's cultural consciousness. But we weren't sure.
Not until I found the proof. The remnants of a Cybergun in one of their labs. I think they were trying to back-engineer it.
But you chose to keep it a secret. Why? Why didn't you warn these people? Both of you know the horrors the Cyber-race is capable of.
It was the mission.
Mission?
There are android agents scattered all across the galaxy, scouring space for Mondasian relics. It's an arms race.
The Earth military are scavenging Cyber-technology to use against us in the Orion War.
I know. And now you're doing the same. How very human of you.
We're fighting a war, Doctor. We have to follow orders. We don't have to like them.
Sara? But, what are you saying?
Riga and his people are doing the same thing as the Earthers. They're using Cyber-hardware to gain an advantage.
That's organics for you. They make the same mistakes, no matter where they are.
And what about us, Temeter? How are we any different? Aren't we supposed to be better than them?
Door opens.
You can't domesticate Cyber-technology. The House of Argentia are playing with fire.
You're wrong, Doctor. We know exactly what we're doing.
I'm sure you believe that.
Show some respect, alien.
You must abandon this technology. It may look like the solution to all your problems, but...
Tasak was aflame, Doctor, our people on the road to extinction, our civilisation in ashes. We brought peace.
Through superior firepower?
Through mutual trust. Not with guns, but with medicines and machines. We have made life better for millions. We truly live in a Silver age, Doctor.
The road to Hell is paved with good inventions.
I told you this was a waste of time, Magus.
We could talk about your operation, Merel, hmm? Your plan? Would the Magus be interested in that?
What does he mean?
Obviously some weak attempt to sow discord among us. Guard, escort the Magus back to the upper decks. We're done here.
Very well.
Know this, off-worlder. I'm the only thing keeping you alive. Remember that the next time you think about opening your mouth. (leaves)
Touchy, isn't he?
All decks stand by for landing stations. Secure the rotors. Hatches away. Watch those safety lines.
My Lord Merel. It is a striking sight, is it not?
I've heard Magus Riga talk of the island's austere, barren grandeur. But now, to see it for myself...
This is only the precursor. When you lay your gaze on the Heart, then you will truly be stirred.
I have no doubt. But there are other matters of more import. The off-worlders. I want you to take them down into the dig site.
Is that wise? What if they...
You'll have guards. I'm charging you with an important task, Ardith. Learn what you can from them. See what they know about the Heart.
You think this Doctor is more than just a reactionary?
He certainly knows more than he's revealed. All his talk of these Cy-bo-men. Use force if you have to.
I er, I'm not comfortable with that notion.
It's for the good of the Argentia, Ardith. Don't cloud the issue with your personal sensibilities.
Keep moving. That way, towards the cave mouth.
Where are they taking us?
Not to be killed. Not yet, anyway.
You're such a ray of sunshine.
I leave all that to you.
I'm glad it was you who came for me.
I wouldn't let it be anyone else.
I'm surprised the War Council gave you the mission.
You're more important to me than some pieces of Cyber-salvage.
That kind of thinking will get you into trouble.
I don't care. (kiss)
All right, you two, keep moving.
Seems a shame to break up the happy couple.
Move it.
Don't mock us, Doctor. Just because our minds are based on silicon and not carbon, that doesn't stop us from having feelings.
I wasn't mocking. Just admiring the delicate complexity of your machine hearts.
Well, in my experience it's organics who have the coldest hearts of all.
Then you've never met a Cyberman.
Get inside.
What's that? The light's reflecting off something in the rock, like steel.
Machined walls. They're embedded in the basalt. They could have been here for hundreds, maybe thousands of years.
Oh no.
All right, that's enough. Keep moving.
The construction matches our scans of Mondasian technology. These walls, the tunnelled corridors radiating off the main cavern, these were made by the Cybermen.
Yes. I was hoping that just one Cyberman had landed here. A single scout, or even just a small
crew. But this?
Doctor?
Well, it's worse than I thought. It so often is.
The Argentia aren't just picking at a piece of space debris, are they?
They're living on a time bomb.
Tomb world. Tasak is a Cyberman tomb world.
One of the countless thousands of them across the galaxy. Planets where the Cybermen secreted armies in suspended animation, dormant in the darkness, sleeping out the centuries.
Waiting for the signal to revive.
And we're standing right in the middle of them.
Everything the Argentia have done, it's all based on a misapprehension.
The great beings from their legends, the prophecy of them merging with their deities. It's a race memory.
Gods from the sky. Yes! A twisted myth based on the Cybermen's plans for galactic domination.
Riga's new machines and medicines, all scavenged from what remains here.

The Argentia have done the Cybermen's work for them. They're seeding Cyber-technology all over the planet. And the moment this hibernation unit activates, what will the Cybermen find waiting for them?
Millions of people primed and ready for Cyber-conversion. A whole planet of new recruits.
Magus Riga?
Hmm? Oh. Specialist Etin. Pardon me, I was preoccupied. I should thank you again for joining us here and for the loan of your aircraft.
You were thinking about that man, the Doctor. His warning.

Yes. And I confess, I cannot put it out of my mind. He spoke with such conviction, such zeal, it... gave me pause. Hmm. Perhaps you might think it shows weakness for me to say this to a former enemy, but in all honesty, I've always been slightly afraid of this place.
The island?
Mmm. And the Heart. And what they represent. Does that make me a fool?
A fool is one who rushes in without forethought. I've always considered you to be a learned man, Magus.
I would not have expected such words from a Sarkota.
There are many among us who admire you and your people, sir. I will admit, I've wondered what my life might've been like if I'd been born into a different cadre. As an Argentia, perhaps.
Oh, thank you, Etin.
And so, I do this with regret. But you will appreciate that I have my orders.
Sarkota troopers? Where, where did they...?
Please don't resist, Magus, I would prefer not to injure you. Take him.
I don't understand.
What do they want with us?
Perhaps we should find out.
The prisoners, sir.
What? Oh yes. Yes, er, thank you.
You don't seem very pleased to see us.
It wasn't my idea to bring you here.
Whose was it? Merel's?
Shut up.
But since we are here, perhaps we can talk as one scientist to another, just for the moment.
Why should I listen to you?
Because you're a scientist, and you have an open mind.
Hmm.
The beings that built this place - the Cybermen - what if they're not dead and gone? What if they're just sleeping?
Impossible.
Have you ever thought that all this is just too good to be true, this treasure trove of miracle technologies?
Too good to be true?
There's no such thing as a free lunch.
Your words make no sense.
There's always a price to pay, Ardith.
If there are Cybermen here, and you're tampering with their technology, they're going to wake up.
And when they do it'll be the end of civilisation on this planet.

And where is your proof of this terrible threat? As one scientician to another I ask you, show it to me. The Heart has brought the Argentian Tasak nothing but prosperity. Show me these destructive monsters you speak of.
If I could do that, it would be too late. You have to trust me.
(laughs) How credulous do you think I am? You look down on us because you're from another world. You think we're primitives. I have yet to believe a single word you utter.
Well, that could have gone better.
Closed minds. Always closed minds. Always, until it's too late.
I can't blame him, though. I don't trust you either, Doctor.

Listen. And with good reason. If the threat of the Cybermen is revealed, then the Argentia will lose their tenuous grip on the peace. The Houses will fragment. The planet will be plunged back into war.
But if we do nothing, and the Cybermen come out of hibernation...
It'll be a bad day for Tasak.
That's an understatement.
Move it.
What is the meaning of this? Merel? Merel, are you all right?
Selfless as ever. You should be more concerned about your own welfare, Riga.
What have you done?
Taken charge. Your time as Magus is over, sir. I have decided to relieve you of your exalted status before it's too late. You've hoarded the power of Argentia for long enough.
Merel, no. You can't do this.
Stay where you are.
So, Etin. I see your noble Duke Hassa has stooped to turning my friend Merel into a traitor.
Merel came to us. He promised certain benefits to the House of Sarkota if the Duke were to assist him with his... ascension.
The Sarkota have been very helpful. Their leader resents you almost as much as I do.
But, but you and I were friends. Colleagues.

I was your servant, always in your shadow. No longer. My agents are already securing my position all over the city, and once I open the Heart, I will be confirmed as the Master of the House of Argentia.
You would jeopardise everything we have done, every step we have taken towards global peace, just to aggrandise yourself? Oh. I don't know you at all.
You never did.
Lord Merel, we need...
Magus Merel.
Of course. How do you wish to proceed?
Have the troopers sweep the dig site and secure it. Gather up all the scienticians and staff.
And if anyone defies us?
Shoot them.
Ma'am.
Do as the Magus says.
Very well. Spread out. Sweep the area and clear.
You’ve betrayed everything we stand for.
Oh, do be quiet.
What was that?
I'm not sure.
Firearm discharge.
Gunshots.
Merel.
You men, with me. Sir, stay back.
What's going on?
Your friend Merel's throwing a palace coup.
Merel? But...
We can't stay here. They're coming this way.
They're between us and the cavern mouth. We'll never be able to make it back to the airstrip.
No one is going anywhere.
Deeper into the caves, then?
Yes.
Ardith, there are other routes through the rock tunnels, yes?
I don't...
This way. Take the chamber. There may be more of them.
Think, man. If we stay here we'll die. Which way do we go?
I... Yes. Follow me. I think we can...
There! More of them. You, halt or we fire!
Quickly!
Over here. There's a service elevator. The shaft feeds into the lower chambers.
Sara, come on.
Temeter?
I'm right behind... Argh!
No!
Sara, just go. Go! Doctor, take her away!
I’m sorry, Sara.
No, I won't let you!
A stupid law unit mistake. Stupid, stupid, stupid.
Well, what have we here?
Hello. I think I've got some bullets belonging to you.
The Heart. It's everything I thought it would be.
You don't deserve to be here.
On the contrary, I think I'm going to get everything I deserve, and more. Accept it, Riga. Take your defeat like a man.
I've never seen anything like this. The etchings, the glyphs on the metal. What do they mean?
The legacy of Mor... of Mondas. The future, Etin, for both our noble Houses.
I won't help you open it.
I don't need you to. Ardith's research isn't as well-guarded as he thinks it is. Troopers, hold him.
Secure the prisoner.
Merel. For Tasak's sake. Don't, I'm begging you.
Are you? Are you really begging me? Go on, then. Get on your knees, beg me, and perhaps I'll relent.
Please, Merel. If you have a single shred of integrity, don't open the Heart with ill-intent. It has been sealed for millennia.
(laughs) The great Riga, humbled. Why, that's made it all worthwhile. But I think I'll do this anyway.
No.
Now you'll have to excuse me. I have a destiny to fulfil. The rest of you will stay here. No one follows me. Understand?
As you wish, Magus.
I do so enjoy the way you say that.
Oh, so cold. This is the Heart. Machines and rimes of ice? Is that all there is?
Gradual build-up of power.
CYBER-CONTROL: No.
(gasp) Who speaks? Wh-what are you?
CYBER-CONTROL: I am awake.

But what are you? A talking machine, some sort of advanced cogitator engine? Listen to me. I am Magus Merel, master of the House of Argentia, and this world is my dominion. Acknowledge me. CYBER-CONTROL: You are incorrect.
You defy me? Explain yourself.
CYBER-CONTROL: This world is not yours. It belongs to us.
I rule here. I am Magus.
CYBER-CONTROL: Incorrect. You are raw material.
What is that? What... what's going on?
CYBER-CONTROL: You will be improved.
No, no, no.
CYBER-CONTROL: You are the first.
Get off me. Let me go. Argh!
CYBER-CONTROL: You will be converted.
No! No!
CYBER-CONTROL: You will become like us.
We have to go back for him. We can't leave Temeter up there.
They'll kill you if you do that. They were Sarkota troopers. I saw the uniforms. They're ruthless. And besides, I doubt your friend would have survived that salvo of shots.
You'd be surprised. He's a lot tougher than he looks.
I won't leave him.
We're not going to, Sara. He'll survive, you know that. Now, come on. We have to move. They
may try and follow us down.
We should go this way. There's a number of vertical vent shafts that extends through these chambers towards the surface of the island.
Come on, then.
It's warmer down here.
Warmer than it should be.
This is a volcanic island, Doctor. It's inert, but there is still some geothermal activity in the deep core.
Even so, it shouldn't be like this. What do we have here?
We channel heat through these bore holes. The thermal differential is used as a power source for the dig site.
You tapped the magma chambers?
Yes, but ... Doctor? What are you doing over there?
In the rock, built into the walls. Sara, what can you see?
I can sense them on the infra-red spectrum. Pods or... coffins.
Cryogenic capsules. And with all this heat, they're thawing out.
There's something inside this one.
Creaking.
Sara, keep away.
Another statue?
It's reacting to us.
Ardith, look out!
What? It's alive.
Humanoid lifeforms will be converted.
Run!
You will become like us.
